title: How to Find Duplicates in Excel

steps.title: Open your original file.
steps.content: Open your original file. The first thing you'll need to do is select all data you wish to examine for duplicates.

steps.title: Click the cell in the upper left-hand corner of your data group.
steps.content: Click the cell in the upper left-hand corner of your data group. This begins the selecting process.

steps.title: Hold down the ⇧ Shift key and click the final cell.
steps.content: Hold down the ⇧ Shift key and click the final cell. Note that the final cell should be in the lower right-hand corner of your data group. This will select all of your data. You can do this in any order (e.g., click the lower right-hand box first, then highlight from there).

steps.title: Click on "Conditional Formatting.
steps.content: Click on "Conditional Formatting. " It can be found in the "Home" tab/ribbon of the toolbar (in many cases, under the "Styles" section). [1] X Research source Clicking it will prompt a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select "Highlight Cells Rules," then "Duplicate Values.
steps.content: Select "Highlight Cells Rules," then "Duplicate Values. " Make sure your data is still highlighted when you do this. This will open a window with customization options in another drop-down menu. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select "Duplicate Values" from the drop-down menu.
steps.content: Select "Duplicate Values" from the drop-down menu. [3] X Research source If you instead wish to display all unique values, you can select "Unique" instead.

steps.title: Choose your highlight color.
steps.content: Choose your highlight color. The highlight color will designate duplicates. The default is light red with dark red text. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click "OK" to view your results.
steps.content: Click "OK" to view your results.

steps.title: Select a duplicate's box and press Delete to delete it.
steps.content: Select a duplicate's box and press Delete to delete it. You won't want to delete these values if each piece of data represents something (e.g., a survey). Once you delete a one-time duplicate, its partner value will lose its highlight.

steps.title: Click on "Conditional Formatting" again.
steps.content: Click on "Conditional Formatting" again. Whether you deleted your duplicates or not, you should remove the highlight formatting before exiting the document.

steps.title: Select "Clear Rules," then "Clear Rules from Entire Sheet" to clear formatting.
steps.content: Select "Clear Rules," then "Clear Rules from Entire Sheet" to clear formatting. This will remove the highlighting around any duplicates you didn't delete. [5] X Research source If you have multiple sections of your spreadsheet formatted, you can select a specific area and click "Clear Rules from Selected Cells" to remove their highlighting.

steps.title: Save your document's changes.
steps.content: Save your document's changes. If you're satisfied with your revisions, you have successfully found and deleted duplicates in Excel!

steps.title: Open your original file.
steps.content: Open your original file. The first thing you'll need to do is select all data you wish to examine for duplicates.

steps.title: Click the cell in the upper left-hand corner of your data group.
steps.content: Click the cell in the upper left-hand corner of your data group. This begins the selecting process.

steps.title: Hold down the ⇧ Shift key and click the final cell.
steps.content: Hold down the ⇧ Shift key and click the final cell. The final cell is in the lower right-hand corner of your data group. This will select all of your data. You can do this in any order (e.g., click the lower right-hand box first, then highlight from there).

steps.title: Click on the "Data" tab in the top section of the screen.
steps.content: Click on the "Data" tab in the top section of the screen. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Find the "Data Tools" section of the toolbar.
steps.content: Find the "Data Tools" section of the toolbar. This section includes tools to manipulate your selected data, including the "Remove Duplicates" feature. [7] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click "Remove Duplicates.
steps.content: Click "Remove Duplicates. " This will bring up a customization window. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click "Select All.
steps.content: Click "Select All. " This will verify all of your columns have been selected.

steps.title: Check any columns you wish to use this tool on.
steps.content: Check any columns you wish to use this tool on. The default setting has all columns checked.

steps.title: Click the "My data has headers" option, if applicable.
steps.content: Click the "My data has headers" option, if applicable. This will prompt the program to label the first entry in each column as a header, leaving them out of the deletion process.

steps.title: Click "OK" to remove duplicates.
steps.content: Click "OK" to remove duplicates. When you are satisfied with your options, click "OK". This will automatically remove any duplicate values from your selection. [9] X Research source If the program tells you that there aren't any duplicates--especially if you know there are--try placing a check next to individual columns in the "Remove Duplicates" window. Scanning each column one at a time will resolve any errors here.

steps.title: Save your document's changes.
steps.content: Save your document's changes. If you're satisfied with your revisions, you have successfully deleted duplicates in Excel!
